description:
Python's fantastic until it isn't. This talk dives into some of the
surprising implementation details of CPython, then explains exactly how
they could be discovered from first principles.

Attendees will leave with some dangerous Python trivia, and the tools
they'll need to uncovery their own trivia when surprises strike.

The talk takes a deep dive into a StackOverflow question asking why
``"x" in ("x", )`` is faster than ``"x" == "x"``
(http://stackoverflow.com/questions/28885132/why-is-x-in-x-faster-than-x-x/28885213#28885213),
including a discussion of ``dis.disassemble``, the Pyhton stack machine,
and reading the CPython source. If time permits, there will be other fun
examples, a whirlwind tour of debugging, and a couple of homework
assignments.
title: When the abyss gazes back: staring down Python's surprising internals
